message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Adaptive Fuzzy Tracking Control for Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With Unknown Control Gain Functions
Paper Abstract: This article investigates the adaptive fuzzy output-feedback backstepping control design problem for uncertain strict-feedback nonlinear systems in the presence of unknown virtual and actual control gain functions and unmeasurable states. A fuzzy state observer is designed via fuzzy-logic systems, thus the unmeasurable states are estimated based on the designed fuzzy state observer. By constructing the logarithm Lyapunov functions and incorporating the property of the fuzzy basis functions and bounded control design technique into the adaptive backstepping recursive design, a novel observer-based adaptive fuzzy output-feedback control method is developed. The proposed fuzzy adaptive output-feedback backstepping control scheme can remove the restrictive assumptions in the previous literature that the virtual control gains and actual control gain functions must be constants. Furthermore, it can make the control system be semiglobally uniformly ultimately boundedness (SGUUB) and keep the observer and tracking errors to remain in a small neighborhood of the origin. The numerical simulation example is presented to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme and theory.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov function"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov%E2%80%93Schmidt_reduction"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lyapunov functions:

## Definition and Purpose

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Applications

The ordinary Lyapunov function is used to test whether a dynamical system is (Lyapunov) stable or (more restrictively) asymptotically stable. Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state x≠0 in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time. For asymptotic stability, the state is also required to converge to x=0.

## Key Properties

A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state. Typically, the function is defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

## Construction and Existence

There is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, in many specific cases the construction of Lyapunov functions is known.(no content)For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.

## Related Concepts

The search results also reveal extensions of the basic Lyapunov function concept, including control-Lyapunov functions for systems with control inputs and ISS-Lyapunov functions for systems with external inputs.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is one of several nonlinear control techniques that takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Application

Systems in strict-feedback form can be stabilized by recursive application of backstepping. This is particularly useful for handling complex nonlinear control problems—rather than having to design a controller for a 100th order system, backstepping can help show that all that's really needed is finding a controller for a 2nd order system and then using backstepping to extend that controller to the 98th other orders.

## Historical Context

Petar V. Kokotovic made contributions to nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Web search results for query: "adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about **adaptive control**:

## Core Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Distinction

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.(no content)Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Types of Adaptive Control

The search results describe several approaches:

- Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters.
- Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Web search results for query: "nonlinear control"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Zero dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_dynamics"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Category:Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Alberto Isidori - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberto_Isidori"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Gain scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gain_scheduling"}]

Here are the search results for "nonlinear control":

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.(no content)The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Analysis and Design Techniques

These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.(no content)Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

## Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off". The furnace is off until the temperature falls below the "turn on" setpoint of the thermostat, when it turns on. Due to the heat added by the furnace, the temperature increases until it reaches the "turn off" setpoint of the thermostat, which turns the furnace off. This cycling of the temperature about the desired temperature is called a limit cycle.

Due to the heat added by the furnace, the temperature increases until it reaches the "turn off" setpoint of the thermostat, which turns the furnace off. This cycling of the temperature about the desired temperature is called a limit cycle.

Based on the search results, here's information about **state observer control**:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Purpose and Importance

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

A simple example illustrates this: vehicles in a tunnel—the rates and velocities at which vehicles enter and leave the tunnel can be observed directly, but the exact state inside the tunnel can only be estimated.

## Design and Implementation

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

## Application with Control

In control theory, a separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system.

Mendel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerry_M._Mendel"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of fuzzy logic systems based on the search results:

## Overview

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic related to fuzzy sets.(no content)A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1.

## Key Characteristics

In mathematics, fuzzy sets (also known as uncertain sets) are sets whose elements have degrees of membership. Unlike traditional binary logic, in a fuzzy rule, the premise x is A and the consequent y is B can be true to a degree, instead of entirely true or entirely false.

## Historical Development

Fuzzy logic was proposed by Lotfi A. Zadeh of the University of California at Berkeley in a 1965 paper.(no content)The first industrial application, a cement kiln built in Denmark, came on line in 1976.

## Applications

Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure".(no content)It has also been used for handwriting recognition in Sony pocket computers, helicopter flight aids, subway system controls, improving automobile fuel efficiency, single-button washing machine controls, automatic power controls in vacuum cleaners, and early recognition of earthquakes through the Institute of Seismology Bureau of Meteorology, Japan.

## Advanced Variations

Type-2 fuzzy sets and systems generalize standard type-1 fuzzy sets and systems so that more uncertainty can be handled.(no content)Type-2 fuzzy sets are finding very wide applicability in rule-based fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) because they let uncertainties be modeled by them whereas such uncertainties cannot be modeled by type-1 fuzzy sets.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of tracking control systems:

## General Overview

A tracking system is a technology used to monitor and record the location and movement of objects or people in real-time or through a historical log. It combines a locating technology, such as GPS, BLE, or RFID, with a software system that collects, processes, and displays the data.

## Key Applications

The primary purpose of a tracking system is to provide location-based data to improve efficiency, safety, and security across a wide range of applications. Some major uses include:

- **Fleet Management**: In logistics and fleet management, these systems form the core of modern telematics, enabling companies to optimize routes, monitor assets, and ensure driver safety.

- **Supply Chain**: They are also used for track and trace solutions in the supply chain, where they are used to ensure product integrity and combat counterfeiting.

- **Consumer Services**: Beyond commercial use, tracking systems are integral to many consumer services, from personal item finders to ride-hailing apps.

- **Virtual Reality**: In virtual space technology, a tracking system is generally a system capable of rendering virtual space to a human observer while tracking the observer's coordinates. For instance, in dynamic virtual auditory space simulations, a head tracker provides information to a central processor in real time.

## Types of Systems

Real-time or near real-time systems provide more immediate data. Global Positioning Systems (GPS), for instance, track location data continuously, with the "real-time" aspect depending on the refresh rate.

For instance, in dynamic virtual auditory space simulations, a head tracker provides information to a central processor in real time.

## Types of Systems

Real-time or near real-time systems provide more immediate data. Global Positioning Systems (GPS), for instance, track location data continuously, with the "real-time" aspect depending on the refresh rate.

Web search results for query: "output feedback control"

Links: [{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about output feedback control:

## Overview

A feedback controller (also called a closed-loop controller) is a control loop which incorporates feedback and uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system. In the context of output feedback control specifically, the focus is on using measured outputs to generate control signals.

## How It Works

The name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.(no content)The control system compares the value or status of the process variable (PV) being controlled with the desired value or setpoint (SP), and applies the difference as a control signal to bring the process variable output of the plant to the same value as the setpoint.

## Common Applications

A proportional–integral–derivative controller (PID controller) is a feedback-based control loop mechanism commonly used to manage machines and processes that require continuous control and automatic adjustment.(no content)An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have advantages over open-loop controllers including disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "fuzzy control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Talk:Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"IEEE 1855 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_1855"},{"title":"Fuzzy Control Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_Control_Language"},{"title":"Type-2 fuzzy sets and systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-2_fuzzy_sets_and_systems"},{"title":"Defuzzification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defuzzification"},{"title":"Fuzzy electronics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_electronics"},{"title":"Force control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_control"}]

## Fuzzy Control Systems

A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1 (true) or 0 (false).

### How Fuzzy Logic Works in Control

Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.(no content)Fuzzy logic is an attempt to apply the easy design of logic controllers to the control of complex continuously varying systems, where a measurement in a fuzzy logic system can be partly true.

### Key Processes

The system involves two important processes:
- Fuzzification is the process of assigning the numerical input of a system to fuzzy sets with some degree of membership, which may be anywhere within the interval [0,1].
- Defuzzification is the process of producing a quantifiable result in crisp logic, given fuzzy sets and corresponding membership degrees. It is the process that maps a fuzzy set to a crisp set and is typically needed in fuzzy control systems.

### Historical Development

Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway. Their ideas were adopted, and fuzzy systems were used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

### Real-World Applications

Matsushita vacuum cleaners use microcontrollers running fuzzy algorithms to interrogate dust sensors and adjust suction power accordingly, and Hitachi washing machines use fuzzy controllers to load-weight, fabric-mix, and dirt sensors and automatically set the wash cycle for the best use of power, water, and detergent.(no content)Canon developed an autofocusing camera that uses a charge-coupled device (CCD) to measure the clarity of the image in six regions of its field of view and use the information provided to determine if the image is in focus. It also tracks the rate of change of lens movement during focusing, and controls its speed to prevent overshoot. The camera's fuzzy control system uses 12 inputs.

Excellent! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**

The paper proposes a novel **observer-based adaptive fuzzy output-feedback control method** for uncertain strict-feedback nonlinear systems. 

**Extracted Triples (8 total):**

1. **Adaptive Control** (proposes) - The paper extends adaptive control with fuzzy logic and state observers to handle unknown control gain functions
2. **Backstepping** (uses) - Fundamental recursive design method adapted for output-feedback control
3. **Fuzzy Logic** (uses) - Used for designing the state observer and control components
4. **Fuzzy Control System** (uses) - Mathematical framework for adaptive fuzzy tracking control
5. **Lyapunov Function** (uses) - Used for stability analysis and control design
6. **State Observer** (uses) - Fundamental to estimating unmeasurable states
7. **Nonlinear Control** (uses) - Core problem domain of strict-feedback systems
8. **Closed-loop Controller** (uses) - Feedback mechanism for output-feedback control

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED
- Paper type: contribution
- Triples: 8
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid
- All required relations satisfied (includes at least one "proposes" for contribution papers)
